text:
Frustrating gotcha, if a line has a trailing blank in the excludesfile file. 
Then that entry doesn't make it into the jar.  When this happens there are no 
warnings about it.  Seems like a trim on all the input lines would do the trick?
creator: paul.hill@ubc.ca
bodewig@apache.org
text: How would you include a file that ends in a blank then?

creator: gus.heck@olin.edu
text:
It sure seems more reasonable to make the knuckleheads with space-ending 
filenames put quotes around their pita files. It seems wrong to supprise users 
who accidentally put in a space at the end of the line...

This sounds hauntingly like tab/space problems in make.
If you put quotes around the filenames, these quotes become part of the filename.
creator: bodewig@apache.org
gus.heck@olin.edu
text:
Well yeah right now they do :) 

My suggestion is that includesfiles and excludesfiles get a bit smarter. I can't
say I've ever heard of a system on which quotes are legally part of a filename.
We certainly quote things with spaces in a lot of other contexts. (which doesn't
mean there isn't such a system, but does mean I tend to think this could be fixed).

> I can't say I've ever heard of a system on which quotes are legally part of a
filename.

we call it unix. 

[slo@eiger slo]$ touch test\"t
[slo@eiger slo]$ ls t*
test"t

Also

1. you would encounter the problem of how to put quotes in quotes in XML. It can
be done but then you have to deal with single quotes in filenames as well as
double quotes

2. what about breaking backwards compatibility.

The latter is critical, we hate to do changes that could break old builds, even
if they are a little ugly., So this stays a wontfix.

However, if you have a patch to the fileset that would print a warning in
-verbose when a trim()'d filename doesnt match the original, we may be able to
provide better diagnostics without breaking anything. How does that sound
creator: stevel@apache.org
gus.heck@olin.edu
text:
Well, I'd forgotten about \" bleh.

I try to forget things like that so I don't use them :)

Certainly better diagnostics is a good idea, but I'd say that this particular
pitfall should be noted in the documentation as well.

What about a trimFileNames atribute or something to make it even more
obvious/convenient to fix/diagnose?

As for a patch... that probably won't happen until I deal with video card 
issues on my home computer. I can't really justify doing this one at work :).
